description:
Triplophysa dalaica is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the genus Triplophysa, which is part of the family Nemacheilidae. This species is native to the Dalahai River basin in Qinghai Province, China.

Triplophysa dalaica is a small, bottom-dwelling fish typically growing up to around 10 centimeters in length. It has a slender, elongated body shape with a rounded snout and small, downward-facing mouth. The fish's coloration is generally brown or grayish-brown with darker mottled patterns along the back and sides.

This species inhabits clear, fast-flowing streams and rivers with gravel or rocky substrates. Triplophysa dalaica is an omnivorous fish, feeding on a variety of aquatic invertebrates, algae, and plant material.

Like other members of the Triplophysa genus, Triplophysa dalaica exhibits adaptations for life in fast-moving freshwater environments, such as a streamlined body shape and the ability to cling to rocks and substrate using specialized fin structures.

Conservation status assessments for Triplophysa dalaica have not been widely reported, but the species is generally considered to have a relatively limited distribution within its native range in the Dalahai River basin.
